name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - the report by Max Andersson, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on certain permitted uses of works and other subject matter for the benefit of the blind, partially sighted and people with disabilities that prevent them from reading print and amending Directive 2001/29 / EC on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society (COM (2016) 0596 - C8-0381 / 2016 - 2016/0278 (COD)) ( A8-0097 / 2017) and - a report by Max Andersson, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cross-border exchange between the Union and third countries of copies of works in a format accessible to people with disabilities to specific works and other subjects oh oh for the benefit of people who are blind, partially sighted or with other disabilities that prevent them from reading the print (COM (2016) 0595 - C8–0380 / 2016 - 2016/0279 (COD)) (A8-0102 / 2017).

name: Max Andersson
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, there are 285 million blind and visually impaired people in the world. Most of them have very little access to books that they can read. Today we can take a major step to change that. Today’s debate is about the implementation of the Marrakech Treaty. This is a Treaty that the Greens, and indeed the whole European Parliament, have been fighting for for years. It creates a copyright exemption in international copyright law for the benefit of blind and visually impaired people so that they can have greater access to books. That is a great thing.  The Marrakech Treaty is an international WIPO treaty, but 30 countries have already joined. What problems does it solve? Today, when you make a copy of a book into a format that blind people can read by, for example, reading it into a computer, you are not allowed to send that book across a border, because of copyright law. The Marrakech Treaty changes that by removing those barriers which prevent libraries and organisations for the blind from sharing books across borders. Why is this important? Most of the 285 million blind and visually impaired people in the world live in countries where there are very few books made accessible in a format that they can read. Most of the books that have been made accessible are in rich countries such as EU countries. By removing the borders, the barriers that prevent the sharing of books, we make books available across the world and we take a major step towards giving blind people much better access to books.  This will be of benefit in EU countries, but the vast improvement will be in countries in Latin America and then Africa and other places where many people speak a European language. This will enable the sharing of books from one country to another and create much better access.  So why has this not been done before? Well, parts of the publishing industry were worried that this copyright exemption might cost them money, so there has been significant lobbying pressure, and the Council was for a very long time unable to decide how to proceed, but now we have finally got there. As Parliament’s negotiator, I am very glad that we have reached a compromise that enables the removal of barriers to the sharing of books across countries.  For many of us, reading books is one of the most important things that we do, and blind people in the world can now have greater access to books. This will make it easier to find a new favourite book.  I would like to thank all the people who have been working for this and I am calling on the European Parliament to vote in favour of the implementation of the Marrakech Treaty because blind people deserve better access to books.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as Mr Andersson has already underlined, the directive and the regulation that we are discussing today jointly implement in EU law the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works for Persons Who Are Blind, Visually Impaired, or Otherwise Print Disabled, which was adopted by the World Intellectual Property Organisation four years ago. This is a very important step for the European Union, one that responds to very concrete needs and one of which we should be very proud. The significance of improving access to books and other printed texts for persons who have disabilities that prevent them from reading in the same way as persons without those disabilities should not be underestimated. So I warmly thank the rapporteur, Mr Andersson, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs for opinion, for their effort and determination in reaching a meaningful outcome in the few months since the adoption of the Commission’s proposals. I am also glad that these proposals have been part of the Commission’s effort to achieve a digital single market in all its dimensions and for all our citizens. They are also the first proposals of our copyright modernisation package from September 2016 to be adopted by Parliament. Still today, too little print material can be accessed by people with print disabilities worldwide. Addressing this problem is fundamental for social inclusion and societal advancement. Doing so will benefit people with print disabilities and it will benefit everybody else. In line with the Marrakesh Treaty, these two pieces of EU legislation will allow the production of copies of works in accessible formats by means of a mandatory exception to copyright, harmonised across the EU. They will also permit the exchange of these copies across borders, within the European Union and with third countries that are parties to the treaty. This possibility for cross-border exchange is very important. It reduces the unnecessary duplication of efforts and costs. It also allows persons with print disabilities to have faster access to a broader range of works than is possible today. I also welcome the fact that the outcome of the negotiations by Parliament and the Council ensures transparency and keeps the burden and complications for beneficiaries to a minimum, for example when it comes to compensation schemes. I trust that we will also be celebrating soon the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty by the European Union, which, together with these proposals, will finally make the treaty a reality for people with print disabilities.

name: Helga Stevens
text: Rap avis EMPL. - The EU is today clearing one of the last hurdles in the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty. People who are blind, visually impaired or with a print disability still have very difficult or no access to books and other printed materials. There is a great need to make more works and other protected material available in accessible formats such as Braille, audiobooks and large print. With the proposals on the table, a new mandatory copyright exception is introduced in EU law in accordance with the Marrakesh Treaty. This will allow beneficiary persons and organizations to make and distribute accessible format copies of works in the EU and third countries party to the Convention. The Marrakesh Treaty is of paramount importance as more than 30 million visually impaired people across the EU will finally have equal access to the printed word. A small step for humanity, a gigantic step forward for blind and partially sighted people!

name: Helga Trüpel
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mister President! This Marrakech Treaty is a major step forward for the blind and visually impaired who are otherwise unable to read printed matter. For years we have had a situation where the hunger for books for the blind and visually impaired could not be satisfied. This Marrakech Treaty is now finally supposed to end that. The market is so small that it has not really paid off for publishers. This is why publishers are now not really threatened by this barrier, which is made mandatory, but for the blind and visually impaired this possibility is a very big step forward. I am copyright-friendly - I am not one of those who want to abolish or significantly restrict copyright - but in this case I find that this limitation is perfectly justified. There may be minor restrictions for publishers. But for the blind and visually impaired it is such an advantage that they can finally get books, other works, that can be exchanged in Europe and internationally. So this is really a humanitarian action, and it is a clear action for cultural diversity - also for people with disabilities. That is why we are so committed to this treaty and want it to be ratified very quickly now.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mr President, Commissioner, honorable Members, and many of my colleagues in the House, I will also speak in support of the Marrakesh Treaty and the agreement reached between the three institutions, and I will emphasize the benefits of this Treaty and its implementation. will bring for the visually impaired and other disabilities. We are talking about more than 30 million visually impaired people living in the Member States of the European Union and their rights and opportunities to access information. The Commission's proposal to implement this treaty comes on time, after there was some misunderstanding in the Council as to who and when should ratify the treaty, given that it was signed in 2013 by more than 60 countries. I thank the colleagues with whom we worked successfully on the opinion prepared by the Committee on Culture and Education, as well as for the successful cooperation with the European Union of the Blind. In addition, I would like to emphasize that Bulgaria is already working on a number of initiatives to further improve access, and I am sure that this cause will be supported even more vigorously during our forthcoming Presidency of the Council.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. - Mr. President, it's a big day. Today this Parliament already gives the go-ahead to the Marrakesh Treaty, which was signed in 2013. It means facilitating access to published works for people with severe visual impairment. It allows - they have said here - the cross-border exchange of books and other materials in accessible formats. That means any kind of format: it can be braille, it can be large print, it can be audio. We have to say that only about 5% of works were accessible at this time and, therefore, there was a lot of material, hunger for reading, that was not accessible to blind people. This generated discrimination and violated the values ​​of which we are a reference today in this Parliament. And that is why it is a great day, because today we are deserving of the concord award. Today we are deserving of the peace prize that we were awarded a few years ago, because today we consolidate the principle of non-discrimination, the principle of equal opportunities, accessibility, participation and effective inclusion in our society. Today we are taking a step so that the right to education can be enjoyed. We also take a step so that all these people can receive and also, in some way, disseminate information; may, like all other people, carry out investigations. It is clear that we had to strike a balance between effective copyright protection, but we also had to serve the general interest. It was a human rights issue. In fact, it is the first human rights copyright treaty, and that is why it is very important, because it connects with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and also with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The benefits are innumerable. First of all, it helps to courageously sensitize all society regarding the challenges and objectives of people with disabilities, especially blind people.We are always saying, from the disability groups, that it is necessary to visualize diversity in a positive way, because that will make society have values.There is a second benefit, and it is access to education.Education is really what sets us free.Education makes us equal in opportunities, and that is why we also take a big step.Social participation and social integration are improved, and poverty is also alleviated, because when this occurs there will undoubtedly be an increase in all contributions to the national economy.We are in luck and today we have shown and we have been deserving of that award for harmony.

name: Margrete Auken
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. - Sir. Chairman! Thank you to everyone here, to Parliament, to Max Andersson and to the Commission. It is many years of effort, which is now hopefully crowned with real success. I will use my short speaking time to still warn about where things can go wrong. The rights holders have been extremely active in lobbying, and my own government has certainly not fared particularly well. On the contrary, it has been a pioneer in ensuring that rights holders are protected from the blind and partially sighted. That is why I would urge the Commission to keep a close eye on what is going on, how the directive is being implemented and to ensure that the existing compensation schemes work smoothly for the blind. It must also be ensured that the wording we have in the settlement, namely that minimal losses are not to be compensated, will work in a way so that it really needs to be documented and proven that there are more than minimal losses. The rights holders find this very difficult. We have confidence in the Commission and we will have confidence in the Court of Justice to ensure that this law is implemented in accordance with the spirit of Marrakesh.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! It is a great pleasure to take part in the debate knowing that the decisions we are taking today are so much expected by millions of our citizens. We know perfectly well how we like to read, what reading gives us: it develops imagination, empathy, allows us to practice synthetic thinking, and delays the processes of dementia. These are all important things, but the most important ones are getting to know the world, our heroes, our past, but also ourselves. Until now, the offer of books and periodicals for the visually impaired and partially sighted people was really very limited, so I am very glad that we managed to negotiate and prepare the implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty, thanks to which millions of our citizens, including almost two million of my compatriots in Poland, they will be able to take advantage of a much wider offer soon. This exception to copyright is fully understandable and fully acceptable. I already have problems with my eyesight, lowercase letters really aren't for me anymore. Therefore, I expect this new offer that will allow you to use the format of an audiobook, capital letter or Braille to be able to read. Mr President, I have one appeal to the Member States to implement these facilities in their countries as soon as possible, in consultation with the organizations of the visually impaired and with publishers.

name: Julie Ward
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it is the right of everyone to fully participate in culture. Yet people who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print disabled continue to face many barriers in accessing books and other print material which is protected by copyright and related rights. The Marrakech Treaty, which allows for copyright exceptions to facilitate the creation of accessible versions of books and other copyrighted works for visually impaired people, was a landmark move to enable visually impaired people to access books with the same ease as sighted readers.  The Marrakech Treaty was adopted in 2013, but the EU has delayed ratifying it, despite its obvious and much-needed benefits for visually impaired people. Whilst working on this subject, I consulted with a cross section of stakeholders – disability experts, NGOs working on disability issues and representatives from the author and publisher fields – and all were largely in agreement with each other and stressed the importance of the speedy ratification of the Treaty. Culture is a human right and equal access to culture is paramount. I would like to thank Luigi Morgano for his help and hard work on this subject.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the negotiations on the adoption of the Treaty of Marrakesh have been disproportionately lengthy, and I am very pleased that we are at the end of this process today and can show the concrete results of our work to those who really need it most. Thanks to this agreement, more than 300 million blind, visually impaired and reading people will have access to books and other printed materials, which has complicated their copyright to this day. Today, only 5% of books are published in formats available to the visually impaired, and in some countries even less. For the visually impaired, it is a fundamental obstacle in terms of access to education. The highest number of these people live in developing and less developed countries. By adopting this agreement, the visually impaired will gain better access to books also thanks to the fact that many organizations will be able to send copies of works to other countries. I would consider it a disgrace if the treaty entered into force without the participation of the European Union. I firmly believe that we will be able to achieve the same success with the so-called Accessibility Act, which we will be discussing here in plenary after the summer holidays, and that we will prove to 80 million Europeans with disabilities that we really want to help them! Thanks for your attention.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Marrakesh Treaty certainly represents an important step for all those people who are visually impaired. This is not a simple treaty, it is about the implementation of fundamental rights for disabled people that have been waiting for a long time, since 2013. The directive and the regulation that we are about to vote on are certainly a fundamental step for the ratification of the treaty. part of the European Union. It ratifies that at this point I hope it will happen as soon as possible and without further hesitation. We have a duty, especially we who are members of the Committee on Culture and Education, to remedy the lack of accessible texts. Of course, in my opinion, the compensation scheme in favor of copyright holders could have been avoided, because this damage resulting from the publication of accessible texts has to be proved. And, in this regard, we have a further task: that of verifying at national level that these compensation schemes are not applied only for the protection of economic profit and to the detriment of people's rights. Protection that, I would like to emphasize, takes precedence over economic profit and must not be just heralded in words, as unfortunately often happens.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, these draft texts adopted in application of the Marrakesh Treaty will help reduce what is called the "book famine", from which the blind and visually impaired as well as people with disabilities suffer. difficulty reading printed texts. I remind you that currently, only between 1 and 7% of works published in the world are available in accessible formats. This is unacceptable. In fact, in Europe, nearly 30 million people are affected. Allow me here to salute the pre-existing initiatives, such as the Tigar project, which has become the ABC's World Book Exchange Service, and in which French publishers have participated in large numbers. The two texts resulting from the trilogue negotiations go in the right direction, with in particular the addition of the electronic book in their scope and of a system of limited compensation for rights holders. I can nevertheless regret that certain existing arrangements in the Marrakesh Treaty and in certain Member States have not been taken up. Although I deny any competence to the European Union to conclude such treaties, the object of these texts obviously goes beyond any other consideration. As a Frenchwoman, from an eminently literary country, I can only be happy with this progress in favor of all these people who will finally be able to have access to a larger part of our heritage.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the Marrakesh Treaty provides for favorable provisions for the blind, the visually impaired or people with visual or reading disabilities, including dyslexia and other learning disabilities which prevent them from reading forms as easily as people without disabilities. This directive comes, on the one hand, to fill some gaps in the provisions for our fellow human beings facing these difficulties and, on the other hand, to introduce a mandatory exemption for certain rights holders' rights which have been harmonized by Union law. Special attention should be paid to the distribution, presentation or distribution of copies accessible to the blind, visually impaired or persons with other reading difficulties or to authorized third-country entities solely on a non-profit basis, from points of sale established within the Union. Finally, it must be ensured that the Contracting Parties provide financial resources and human resources to facilitate international cooperation between the Authorized Entities and ensure adequate availability of copies in an accessible format and the cross-border exchange of such copies.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European Union law will finally be brought into line with the international requirements of the Marrakesh Treaty. Finally, access to books and other printed materials protected by copyright and related rights will be facilitated for blind, visually impaired, dyslexic or other people with disabilities who are not allowed to read printed materials. I am glad that these pieces of legislation will be adopted and will make life easier for millions of European citizens. Their educational opportunities will also improve. The adoption of this legislation will also improve the exchange of audiobooks and other printed materials accessible to the visually impaired. From now on, it is important for the Member States to launch initiatives to promote the objectives of the Marrakesh Treaty, so that our citizens can make the most of the opportunity provided to them.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: - Mister President! The implementation of the Marrakech Treaty is long overdue and today the time has finally come. Access to published works for blind, visually impaired or print disabled people will be made easier in the European Union, thus ensuring cultural participation. We are facilitating both intra-Union access and cross-border exchanges, and I hope that Member States will act swiftly on implementation and application. It was particularly important to us as the S&D group that we had a short implementation period and that we could live with twelve months. It is also good that there will be no commercial availability check. This test would have significantly reduced the availability and accessibility of the works. Finally, it is gratifying that the legislation also includes digital formats and is therefore future-proof. In addition, we will be closely following the Commission's report on a possible expansion of the scope in order to be able to include further works.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the right to read and to know is a right to culture. We have technological development that gives us huge potential. How long should visually impaired people feel doubly excluded, because of their disability initially, but also because of the indifference of today's society to give them the rights enjoyed by their good fellow citizens? That is why supporting the Marrakesh Treaty for its transposition into European law is a matter of social justice. Ladies and gentlemen, I have not always had vision problems and I understand the difference. So, I know how beneficial it would be for all of us to be able to read and overcome the darkness of sight through the light of reading.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, reading is essential for the acquisition of a thorough culture and, consequently, for the development of the human person. It is therefore necessary to provide specific devices to allow the blind and visually impaired to access them as well. This is the meaning of the directive and the regulation presented today. So I agree with their general philosophy. The European Union must however remain modest, because it is the Marrakesh Treaty of 2013, of which the two texts are only a transposition, which constituted a major advance for the blind, by granting books intended for them copyright exemptions or exceptions. We must therefore congratulate ourselves on the progress made, while stressing that it is due to the World Intellectual Property Organization, which inspired the treaty, and not to the Union. The Marrakesh Treaty represents a victory for solidarity over financial pressure groups. It’s rare enough to be worth celebrating.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - The directive on the provision of the Marrakesh Treaty will be another step in the direction of responding to the needs of every citizen of the European Union. It is a huge thing for the blind and visually impaired if copyrighted works are freely accessible, regardless of borders. This is an area where decisions must be made not in the interests of trade but in accordance with the principle of fairness. That is why I am puzzled by the part of the agreement that raises the possibility of paying financial compensation that visually impaired organizations and libraries should pay. Given the high cost of producing special publications for the visually impaired, such an additional tax could deprive additional blind and visually impaired citizens of access to books, especially in poor Member States. As it will be up to the Member States to apply this financial compensation, governments, rather than the EU, must be fair and wise in this matter.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that with these two provisions, cultural rights, which are an integral part of human rights, formally form part of the acquis communautaire, now that finally Europe, the The European Union as such, which had signed the Marrakesh Treaty in 2013, adopts it a few years later. It was a great victory for the associations, but also for a Parliament that was really committed alongside the Commission to get this step forward. I think it is also important that not only blind people, but also people with disorders such as dyslexia or reading and learning disorders, are included in this access. But we also know that, in order for the exceptions to copyright to be fully functional, there must be a relationship of collaboration, of trust, between the organizations authorized to make copies in accessible format of literary works and the publishers, for these to be , in fact, authorized and recognized by the Member State of establishment. We have therefore created the conditions for this to become really effective and not just a wish.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we have repeatedly discussed in the Committee on Petitions the need to implement the Marrakesh Treaty, as we have received hundreds of petitions from our fellow citizens. We have also dealt with this issue in plenary here, and the progress that is being made today is important, because some Member States did not want to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty and used various tricks. This is an important Treaty, which really provides a service to those of our fellow citizens who are blind or have vision problems or learning needs. It will now be possible for these people to have access to texts that they could not have, thus strengthening their right to education and cultural property. But we must pay attention to the various tripods that put some lobbies who want to retain rights in relation to copyright issues. This is important and we must be careful because access is required to be immediate and unrestricted.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, we only give the intentions enshrined in the proposals under discussion that go the way of guaranteeing access to blind or visually impaired people to printed texts, namely integrating the perspective of access to texts and works made available in digital or audio format. It is a factor of social justice and equity in access to information, culture and knowledge that millions of people today have different difficulties in accessing. We cannot, however, disconnect the matter under consideration and the reality that is described from the consequences of austerity policies, policies to attack public services, the attack on social and labor rights and the many restrictions that have been imposed and expanded in many countries. , as in Portugal, in the rights of people with disabilities, a population group particularly vulnerable to poverty and social exclusion. Only through public service policies will it be possible to guarantee equal access and participation in the social, economic, cultural or sporting dimensions of life.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, people who are blind, have visual impairments or have other difficulties in accessing printed texts continue to face many obstacles to accessing printed material. The need to make the number of works much wider in accessible formats entirely available to these people and to improve their circulation was recognized by the Treaty of Marrakesh, as has already been said. The European Union's accession to the Marrakesh Treaty has been long awaited. However, and despite its signature by the European Union in 2014, the truth is that its rectification remains delayed for a purely legal matter. The truth is that it is a matter of enormous importance, insofar as it guarantees a basic human right to more than 30 million visually impaired people across the European Union and improves accessibility to books in developing countries . The result of this delay is that these citizens continue to face many obstacles to accessing books and printed material and all that this implies in terms of social exclusion. Dear Colleagues, I would like to note that this draft resolution is a triumph for a social model of disability, it represents an adequate international solution to the global problem of book hunger. For all these reasons, I believe it is necessary to take all the necessary measures to ensure the rapid and appropriate application of the treaty, which has an enormous cultural, humanitarian and social development dimension.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, people who are blind, partially sighted or with other reading difficulties continue to face serious problems in accessing books and other copyrighted material. These people must have the same right as everyone else to access information and participate in cultural, economic and social life. It is important that Europe strives to increase the availability of works translated into formats accessible to the blind, starting first with improving the circulation of those available in the internal market. Some progress has already been made with the Marrakesh Treaty, but much remains to be done, especially by making intelligent use of new technologies, which can prove decisive for access to education and for the social inclusion of these people. The social inclusion of the blind is an integral part of the United Nations Convention, but it is also a moral and civil obligation of our society, which we cannot avoid. The European Union and the Member States must rapidly proceed to recognize these rights.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there is no doubt that today is a big day. It is an enormous step and this discussion demonstrates that Parliament shares the Commission’s view that the active inclusion and full participation of people with disabilities in society is not only worth pursuing but is imperative. The proposals we are discussing today are indeed one piece of the broader action that the European Union is taking in this area, including the recent Web Accessibility Directive, the Commission’s proposal for a European Accessibility Act, as mentioned by some honourable Members, and its broader European Disability Strategy. With regard to speeding up the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, we agree that the EU should proceed rapidly to ratification. The Commission proposed a decision of the Council to that effect more than one-and-a-half years ago. We encourage the Council to adopt a decision as soon as possible. A recent Court of Justice opinion has removed any doubt about the exclusive competence of the Union to ratify it, so there is therefore no good reason for further delaying the ratification of the treaty. I would like to answer some questions and make some remarks about Member State compensation schemes. The Commission is ready to support Member States in the transposition of this legislation into their national law. As with all new legislation, the Commission will also monitor its correct transposition in its application to make sure that its overall implementation is faithful to the principles contained in the directive. This also applies to the provision that allows Member States to have compensation schemes, as politically agreed during the negotiation of this directive, and to the clear limits to those schemes set out in the directive itself. In summary, I am glad to witness that the common objective of Parliament, the Council and the Commission to proceed to a fast and smooth adoption of this proposal has been achieved. Once again I want to thank Parliament for these important results. I would like to thank the rapporteur and others for your contribution in this enormous step.

name: Max Andersson
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am very glad to hear that there is so much unity about something that is this important. I have just one substantial thing to add and that is that I will be sure to agree with the Commissioner when he calls for the Council to ratify this quickly. However, quickly in the European Union is not always fast. It will take at least a year for the Member States to implement this before we can ratify and start sharing books for blind people across borders. I want to emphasise that the Council, which I know is working on this issue, needs to act quickly. For blind people all over the world this will give greater and better access to books and it is now up to the Council to deliver. I would like once again to thank the Commission for its very serious and good approach. It has really been a positive influence. I would also like to thank the Maltese Presidency for helping to find a good compromise. Most importantly, I would like to thank the European Blind Union, which has been an immense asset in this work. It is one of the driving forces behind the Marrakech Treaty. I would, of course, like to thank once again all the colleagues who have been working on this for years. Blind people should have better access to books.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 6 July 2017.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Sirpa Pietikäinen, Renata Briano, Mark Demesmaeker, Catherine Bearder, Anja Hazekamp, Keith Taylor, Eleonora Evi on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on huntingfor whales in Norway (O – 000058/2017 - 2017/2712 (RSP) - B8–0324 / 2017).

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: author. – Mr President, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) put in place a worldwide moratorium on commercial whaling in 1986. Nevertheless, Norway continued whaling and fully resumed commercial whaling activities in 1993, using a formal objection to the moratorium, as well as reservations to CITES listings. Norway establishes its own catch limits. For this year’s whaling season it increased the quota of North Atlantic minke whales to 999, up from 880 last year. Norway’s exports of whale meat have increased sharply in recent years. Some of these exports are shipped through EU ports. For example, according to animal welfare institutes, in October last year alone almost 3 00 kilos of Norwegian whale products were exported to Japan, having transited through at least three EU ports. The transit of whale meat through EU ports is permitted provided that shipments are accompanied by valid CITES documentation on the Council’s regulation. What action has the Commission taken so far to persuade Norway to halt its whale hunting and adhere to the IWC moratorium? Will the Commission use its influence at upcoming CITES and IWC meetings to urge contracting governments to adopt a common position urging Norway to put an immediate stop to all whaling activities? Can the Commission provide data on the quantities of whale meat shipments transported through EU ports, their destinations and whether they are accompanied by valid CITES documentation? What measures is the Commission taking to ensure that this documentation obligation is strictly enforced? Does the Commission agree that, by allowing the transit of whale meat through its ports, the EU is facilitating trade in whale species which are protected by multiple EU laws and whose hunting contravenes the current international ban on commercial whaling? What does the Commission believe can be done to prohibit such shipments at both EU and Member State level? If no agreement is reached with Norway, will the Commission recommend a ban on whale meat transit through EU ports as an exceptional measure?  I hope that the Commission can give very clear answers and also take prompt action because whale hunting – the hunting of endangered species – is inhumane and breaches international legislation. That is something which is not acceptable, so hopefully we can act together to end Norway’s unacceptable practices.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I shall try to answer all these questions on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Vella. The European Union is fully committed to the conservation of all cetaceans and is equipped with environmental legislation to pursue this objective. Commercial whaling is not allowed in the Member States’ waters or by ships under the jurisdiction of a Member State. All whale species are protected from deliberate disturbance, capture or killing under the Habitats Directive. In addition, imports to and exports from the EU of cetaceans for primarily commercial purpose are banned under our wildlife regulations. The European Union has consistently supported in the International Whaling Commission (IWC) the global moratorium on commercial whaling. It has also clearly positioned itself against trade in whale products in CITES meetings. It is therefore problematic that Norway, a European country, not only continues to take whales for commercial purpose but has also become the most prolific world whaler, killing more whales in the past two years than Japan and Iceland combined. Norway’s practice of exporting whale products via EU Member States’ ports also threatens the consistency of EU policies in relation to whales and other cetaceans. The EU has made its position clear to Norway. Firstly, at the last International Whaling Commission meeting in October 2016, the Union invited Norway to cease its whaling activities. The EU also called on Norway to stop its trade in whale products – a call which it also addressed to Iceland and Japan – and to reconsider its reservations on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) listing of large whales. In November 2016, my colleague Commissioner Vella discussed this issue with the Norwegian Minister for Environment, Vidar Helgesen, who confirmed the Norwegian position, referring to the fact that ‘only’ 17 Norwegian vessels catch minke whales. Still, these 17 vessels killed 1 251 minke whales during 2015 and 2016! In December 2016, the Council adopted new and stronger conclusions on EU relations with the non-EU Western European countries, calling on Norway and Iceland to respect the internationally agreed moratorium on commercial whaling and to withdraw reservations under CITES. Given its reservation on the CITES listing of large whales, Norway can, however, trade whale products with other countries which have the same reservations, provided that such products have valid CITES export permits. The transit of such shipments via EU Member States is also legal under international law, provided that the authorities in the Member States can check that the shipments are accompanied by valid CITES permits. I need to say that the EU Member State authorities are fully aware of their obligations to control shipments transiting through their ports. The Commission has discussed this transit issue with them on several occasions. We do not have statistics on the extent of this transit but, at the same time, we are not aware of shipments of whale meat which would have gone through EU territory without the required documentation. The Commission will continue to take a strong position on this subject and to work with its international partners to engage with Norway towards reaching decisions more consistent with the EU approach and leading to better conservation of whales worldwide.

name: Paul Rübig
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mister President!I am a member of the SINEEA delegation and the delegation for the European Economic Area.It is clear to us that Norway has filed an objection to the moratorium with the international convention on whaling and is therefore not bound by this moratorium under international law.As an Austrian, however, animal-friendly fishing methods are particularly important to me.I believe that it is crucial that new training methods are found for small and medium-sized fishermen.We know there are around 100,000 minke whales;one percent is currently fishing and being caught.It goes without saying that whale fish is used very traditionally as a food in Norway and the nature conservation regulations must also be observed here.

name: Renata Briano
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, about a year ago we were here in plenary asking to stop the slaughter of whales carried out by Japan. Today we are here again for the same reason, but for a different country. Norway has systematically hunted whales for commercial purposes since the 1930s and, despite the international moratorium that came into force in 1987 - I would say back in 1987 - it has never stopped killing and trading these whales, based on alleged scientific purposes. I say "presumed" because, as I said for Japan, this "scientific evidence" often ends up on supermarket shelves or on restaurant plates. In recent years the business has even grown, so much so that the Norwegians hunted more whales than Japan and Iceland combined in 2014 and 2015, earning the sad role of world leader in the field of this hateful practice. One fact: the Norwegian share of fin whales has gone from 880 specimens in 2016 to 999 this year. Today we are complicit in the Norwegian slaughter, as currently EU legislation allows the transit of whale meat if accompanied by CITES documentation. To give an example, from January to October 2016 about three tons passed through Union ports, without thinking of all the meat traded in other ways. We therefore ask the Commission to intervene decisively, resolutely, and that the close natural relationship that exists between Norway and the European Union does not become a shield against which we cannot expose ourselves, but rather that it be used as a direct channel to influence Norwegian decisions.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Commercial whaling has been banned worldwide for over 30 years, and yet countries like Norway are proving stubborn. Norway resumed commercial whaling in 1993. The country draws up its own fishing quotas and these are increasing. This year, nearly 1,000 North Atlantic minke whales will be caught and killed and exports of whale meat are also increasing. I took the initiative to put this topic on the agenda, because we must continue to raise these horrific practices. The whale is an iconic and beloved animal that deserves our protection. Whaling does not only undermine the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems. It also violates international law. Moreover, there is no public support for it. Thank you for your reply, Commissioner, and I understand that you share our concerns. We are, I think, on the same side and our message must therefore be that we continue to encourage you to do everything in your power to get Norway to respect the global moratorium. Our ports must not, as it were, become complicit in illegal shipping. I understand from your answer that we need more data and figures on that, that we need more control. I encourage you to work on that too.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - It took some effort, but we managed to discuss Norwegian whaling here in the European Parliament. And that is badly needed, because Norway has been ignoring the international ban on commercial whaling for more than 30 years. Since the ban, Norway has killed more than 13,000 whales and the hunt is now in full swing for nearly 1,000 whales, including pregnant animals. That is a great shame. You must protect endangered animals and not kill them with harpoons. Because most Norwegians have long stopped eating whale meat, some of the whale meat is used as animal feed for the animals in the fur industry. The remainder of the whale meat left over by Norway from its barbaric whaling hunt is shipped to Japan via European ports. In this way, Europe is participating in the whale meat trade. That really has to stop! We ask the European Commission to stop cooperating in the transport of illegally killed whales. Mr President, this legal opinion shows that the European Commission has the options to stop the transport of whale meat via European ports, also with CITES papers. In the words of Mr Juncker, you could call it ridiculous that the responsible Commissioner has not bothered to be here today. But I have every confidence that Commissioner Stylianides will explain how the Commission and the Member States will close European ports to whale meat as soon as possible. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Keith Taylor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, over the past few years Norwegian whalers have hunted more whales than Iceland and Japan combined. In 2016 alone, 591 minke whales were killed, and for 2017 the quota has been set for 990 whales. Yet in Norway, as was previously said, the domestic demand for whale meat has fallen to the point that unwanted whale meat is now being sent to fur farms to be used as feed. What a doubly grotesque state of affairs that is. This decline in demand should not come as any surprise, given the very high levels of toxic contaminants found in whale products, including PCBs, hormone-disrupting chemicals and mercury. Sadly, as large mammals, whales are greatly at risk from persistent organic pollutants because of bio-accumulation in the food chain. In fact, the Japanese Government itself has rejected imports of Norwegian whale meat after tests revealed pesticide levels double the amount Japan permits in imports, making the meat unfit for human consumption, so that it simply has to be destroyed. Despite this, Norway has sharply increased its exports to Japan. However, as there is no direct shipping route to Asia, EU ports offer a convenient stopping off point for the ships. In the European Union our legislation could not be any clearer: all cetacean species are strictly protected and any incidental capture, killing or sale by EU Members is prohibited. Under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), international trade in whale products is also specifically prohibited. It simply beggars belief that the EU is assisting another country that holds the polar opposite views and values on this issue to transport whale meat via its ports. This clearly goes against our conservation laws designed to protect these magnificent creatures. I would like the Commission to give Parliament all the data available on these exports, to use its influence in CITES and in the International Whaling Commission to encourage Norway to end its cruel and unnecessary practice of whaling. If this does not result in the desired outcome, I call on the Commission to recommend a ban on whale-meat transiting through EU ports, as an exceptional measure.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the increase in whale catches by Norway is of particular concern, especially when it comes to pregnant females. However, Norway, which is not a member of the European Union, had chosen to oppose the 1986 global moratorium on whale catches. Also, in order to convince this country to apply this moratorium, the room for maneuver of the European Commission is particularly weak. An embargo or bans on the transit of whale meat in European ports would constitute punitive, but not constructive, sanctions. As the world is not just the European Union, whale meat would continue to circulate in the ports of third countries. So let's deal with the problem at the source within the framework of the CITES convention and the International Whaling Commission, two organizations of which Norway is a member. Let the States act together on such a delicate subject.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you ... yesterday I was here, late at night; today we meet in the morning ... A lot has happened since the ban on whaling in Norway at the beginning of the 20th century, an activity that, in fact, dates back to the 7th century, but, over time, the interest and domestic demand for whaling products in Norway has been declining. Despite the moratorium that we all gave ourselves in 1986 through the International Whaling Commission, for the sake of preservation, Norway never fully applied it and in 1993 it resumed hunting cetaceans for commercial purposes, eventually catching —se He has already said this morning, on several occasions - in recent years more exemplary than Japan and Iceland combined. I want to recall - yesterday we discussed about it - Goal 14 of the 2030 Agenda: conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development. The Union must lead the achievement of these objectives and, therefore, it must also be able to control that the goods arriving at its ports comply with all legal requirements.

name: Marco Affronte (Verts/ALE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time we have talked about whaling in this House: I remember at least three or four discussions in the last two years, even though the defendant on the bench was usually Japan and not Norway. Each time we end up with two considerations: the first is that the whole Chamber condemns this practice, which by now no longer has a reason to exist, which is a practice of the past and which is human, and the second point that always emerges is frustration for not having any concrete possibility of doing anything to stop this type of whaling by both Japan and Norway. This time, in these days, we have the opportunity to do something a little more concrete, finally, from two points of view. The first is this passage of whale meat in European ports: it is not enough for the Commission to say that they have all the documents in place, we can actually do something to try to stop it. And the second thing: we are currently negotiating the trade treaty with Japan; why not also remember within that treaty that we do not want Japan to continue hunting whales?

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although in 1986 the international whaling commission imposed a worldwide moratorium on commercial whaling, the truth is that Norway continues to hunt whales and establish its own catch limits. The fact is that Norway even increased in 2017 the share of dwarf whales caught in the North Atlantic to 999, compared to 880 in 2016, and between 2014 and 2015 killed more whales than Japan and Iceland combined, as said the Commissioner just now. Commissioner, most of the dead whales are pregnant females, as shown in the documentary "battle of the agony" with terrible images from the Norwegian whaling industry, including a bloody scene during which a fisherman cuts a pregnant whale. Dear colleagues, whale hunting is now more unacceptable than ever. Commissioner, the Commission must take urgent action to adopt a common position to urge Norway to immediately end all whaling activities under the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling. The products derived from the whales are exported from Norway to Japan and I finish, Mr. President, saying that through at least three ports in the European Union. The European Union cannot allow this. Commissioner. I call on you to put an end to this situation once and for all. It is unacceptable, at this moment, to continue watching the bloody scenes that we have seen.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr President, come on, 1,250 whales captured by Norwegian whalers between 2015 and 2017 despite the international moratorium of 1987, it is not tolerable. The European Union must do everything possible to ensure that Norway puts an end to these practices. The first step is to convince the Norwegian whale hunters themselves that at this rate they will soon have nothing to hunt. Then, we must act politically with the Norwegian government, partner of the European Union, so that it takes its responsibilities, but - it seems to me - the strongest means at the disposal of the European Union is that of control. commercial. Ensuring transparency by checking CITES documents in ports is undoubtedly a heavy burden, but it is necessary in order to be respected. At a time - and this has been said by several colleagues - when we are negotiating a trade treaty with Japan, a consumer of whale meat, we would do well to see this issue addressed in official documents.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, whaling for commercial purposes has been banned worldwide, through the moratorium imposed by the International Whaling Commission. But we see that countries like Japan and Norway are constantly violating and violating the decisions of the international community. Thus, Norway has continued whaling since 1993, violating the moratorium and the CITES list. For 2017, Norway increased its whaling quota from 880 to 999 humpback whales. In fact, Norway uses European Union ports to export whale products to Japan. How does the Union allow the transit of whale meat through European Union ports, when this requires cargo to be accompanied by valid CITES documents? Who issues these documents? Or is whale meat finally trafficked without these documents, so we are in breach of Council Regulation 338/1997?

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Arctic seas are already those at greatest risk today and those where the effects of climate change are most evident. Unfortunately, there are those who see only great earning opportunities in the melting of the Arctic ice: from the extraction of fossil fuels to mining activities and the opening of new fishing areas and shipping routes. This is an alarming scenario. It is an alarming scenario in which we must do our best to prevent harmful and useless whaling from adding to global degradation. Hunting that Norway has increased over the last few years, including for commercial purposes. We must do everything, use all the pressure tools we have, so that Norway respects the moratorium of 1986 and that the ports of the European Union carry out the appropriate checks and are not complicit in this illicit trafficking and this absurd practice that still today , in 2017, takes place.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, we live in a time when the destruction of the planet and the environment tends to be irreversible. Both scientists and environmental organizations warn. We all experience the effects in our daily lives with climate change and rising global temperatures. To this catastrophe is added the greed of the people, who in the face of profit respect nothing. Whales are mammals that have lived on the planet for millions of years and are known to be endangered due to marine pollution, but also due to overfishing. Norway begins the most horrible custom this year; the annual slaughter of hundreds of pregnant whales. Every year pregnant whales are minced to make cosmetics and animal feed. They consider the pregnancy of female whales a sign of good health. Norway is the number one killer whale. This year the government announced that it intends to double the number of whales it kills. They then export the meat abroad through European ports. Norway has not been sanctioned for its mass killings. Today, therefore, we must all send a strong message to Norway, but also to awaken those who do not know about this crime.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the speakers for their constructive comments. I have already underlined some steps that have been taken by my colleague Commissioner Vella to put pressure on Norway to stop whale hunting, and I would like to answer the question: why does the Commission not have information about the quantities and destinations of whale meat transported via EU ports? From my homework on the subject, it is clear that the Commission does not have statistics on the quantities of whale meat transiting through ports of EU Member States, as there is no obligation under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to report the volume of CITES-listed products transiting through the territories of CITES states parties. The authorities in the EU Member States are, however, fully aware of their obligations to control shipments of CITES-listed products transiting through their ports. The Commission has discussed this issue with EU Member States on several occasions. As I stated before, the Commission intends to make sure that the EU continues to take an active position on whaling and works with its international partners to press for decisions consistent with the EU approach and leading to better conservation of whales worldwide. For that reason, the Commission will present in September a proposal for a Council decision establishing the position to be adopted on behalf of the European Union at the next three meetings of the International Whaling Commission, including related inter-sessional meetings and actions. This proposal might also be the basis for further EU bilateral action vis-à-vis whaling countries.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place in September.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU has consistently supported in the International Whaling Commission (IWC) the global moratorium on commercial whaling. It has also clearly positioned itself against trade in whale products in CITES meetings. It is therefore problematic that Norway not only continues to take whales for commercial purposes but has also become the most prolific world whaler, killing more whales in the past two years than Japan and Iceland combined. Norway’s practice of exporting whale products via EU Member States’ ports also threatens the consistency of EU policies in relation to whales and other cetaceans. Animals are sentient beings. Whether they are wild, farm or domestic, animals should be treated with dignity and respect. Animals have no voice or vote to protest against the atrocious behaviour of humans. We have to show how civil and caring we are by giving voice to these beings – which at times are more civil and loving than man. Therefore, it is extremely important that the EU continue to take its strong position and necessary measures, together with its international partners, to engage with Norway towards reaching decisions more consistent with the EU approach and leading to better conservation of whales worldwide.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo and Lee Miong-che (2017/2754 (RSP)).

name: Helga Trüpel
text: Author. - Mister President! Ladies and gentlemen, the human rights situation in China has unfortunately worsened again in recent years, especially after Xi Jinping became president. Liu Xiaobo received the Nobel Peace Prize for his advocacy for human rights, the separation of powers, the rule of law and the protection of minorities. His arrest and long 11-year sentence have always been wrong - just as house arrest has always been wrong for his wife - and sheer harassment by the Chinese government. Now Liu Xiaobo is seriously ill. We demand his immediate release from custody - he has not yet been released, he has only been transferred to a hospital. We require that he can meet his friends and lawyers and that he can travel and be free to choose where to seek treatment. That is a clear political request to the Chinese government, and it is a clear humanitarian obligation not to keep such a seriously ill person in this terrible detention. I also demand that this question be discussed at the G20 summit in Hamburg.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, we stand with those who fight for human rights and freedom of expression across the world. Liu Xiaobo and Lee Ming-che have experienced the deprivation of their liberty and basic human rights for too long. Their cases are not isolated. While we welcome the news that Liu Xiaobo has been a released from prison on medical parole, this is ultimately too little and too late. Taiwanese activist Lee Ming-che remains detained without clear or credible allegations proved against him. Activists who are simply doing their job are being repressed and imprisoned. All activists imprisoned for legitimate activities must be immediately and unconditionally released.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: Author. - Liu Xiaobo spent eleven years in detention, without due process, without contact with his family, in poor conditions, and until a serious liver cancer became undeniable. And his chair also remained empty at the presentation of his Nobel Prize. This man is one of the most admirable people in the world. He has given up his freedom for his activism. The same goes for Lee Ming-che. He too is a victim of China's repressive policies. He too is an activist who has given up his freedom to fight for human rights. In fact, it is high time that we from Europe gave a clear signal to China: release the human rights activists immediately. They don't belong in captivity. Two, of course give them the necessary medical assistance, that is also dignified. And three, and that is something I keep asking the European Union again and again: we must continue to fight for human rights around the world. These two men have already saved many lives with their sharp pens and peaceful commitment. Now it is up to us to do the same for them.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, the cases of Liu Xiaobo and Lee Ming—che are very concerning, but sadly unsurprising and, in fact, predictable, given the severe lack of freedom of speech and expression that we are now all too familiar with in the People’s Republic of China. They form part of a systematic crackdown on civil society and opposition to the one-party politics of the PRC. Therefore I echo the calls in the resolution of this House to see the release of both the individuals in question and hope that Xiaobo and his wife will be given permission to leave the country, if desired, in view of Xiaobo’s ongoing serious medical needs. Meanwhile, the situation in Tibet, the plight of the Falun Gong in Hong Kong, the fate of democracy in the two systems, one country policy, and the issues of media and internet freedom are all areas of major concern to the European Union. China is a global power that we are unable to ignore, but this should not mean that we shy away from highlighting areas of concern where we see them, nor deny the importance that we place upon fundamental and universal human rights.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: author. – Madam President, the case of Liu Xiaobo and Lee Ming—che are different from each other but are both attributable to similar reasons. We strongly condemn the long-term persecution of this most famous Chinese dissident who got inspiration from Václav Havel. Liu Xiaobo is seriously ill and near death.  A different case is a young men from Thailand, Lee Ming-che who came to China to talk about human rights and was arrested without any evidence. His case also points to the absence of rule of law in China. He is In fact, a citizen of another country which China treats as its territory. There are many persecuted people in China. We cannot name them all, but we have therefore symbolically added a reference to the recently arrested Catholic Bishop Peter Shao Zhumin. We should strengthen our human rights dialogue with China regardless of our economic interests. Thank you, colleagues, for your support.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, the fate of Liu Xiaobo, Nobel Peace Prize winner, shows what the brutal repression exercised by the Chinese authorities on dissidents represents. Liu Xiaobo's only crime, arbitrarily sentenced to eleven years in prison, was to demand constitutional reforms and respect for democracy and human rights. By putting Liu Xiaobo behind bars, China has not only jailed a man, it has locked away the democratic hope of an entire nation. Chinese authorities waited until his cancer was terminal before granting him parole. They do not even have the decency to let him choose to be treated anywhere other than in a country that persecutes him. Like Liu Xiaobo, Taiwanese human rights defender Lee Ming-che has been arrested for subversion. Chinese freedom-killing laws on national security give the regime absolute power to muzzle NGOs and civil society. For Liu Xiaobo and Lee Ming-che, we demand immediate and unconditional release.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President! If our relations with China are to work in the long term, one must also treat one another honestly. So we need to talk about human rights. Two cases concern us today - two of many, mind you. Cases that contradict all international conventions to which the People's Republic of China has also acceded. The case of Lee Ming-che also contradicts the bilateral mutual legal assistance agreement between Taiwan and China. The Chinese authorities should have immediately informed Taiwan of the arrest on March 19. Since then, there has not been any satisfactory information about his whereabouts and the circumstances under which he is being held. We therefore demand immediate information on the facts, the right to legal assistance and medical care, and immediate release should the allegations prove to be unfounded.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- A great man in a great country: Nobel laureate, scientist, publicist Liu Xiaobo.In these sad times of serious illness, the European Parliament sympathizes intensely with him and his wife.Liu Xiaobo has a poignant message for us, I quote: “Tyranny is not terrifying;what is really scary is submission, silence, and even praise for tyranny.As soon as people decide to oppose it to the bitter end, even the most vicious tyranny will be short-lived. ”In his 2009 lawsuit, Liu Xiaobo argued against the “psychology of hate” that blocks a real modernization and democratization of China.He personally applied this principle by praising his guard Liu Zheng for his attitude of “respect and empathy”.Liu Xiaobo: a great man in a great country!

name: Frédérique Ries
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate is slowly dying out in China, released from prison to silence the outcry, hidden somewhere now in a hospital in the north of the country, far from the turmoil and protest of the world. Liu Xiaobo is dying. Her liver cancer has become widespread and Beijing, however, continues to deny her family's request for treatment abroad. But, let us be reassured, foreign doctors have just been invited to come to the bedside of the peace activist and, of course, the participation, from tomorrow, of President Xi Jinping in the G20 in Hamburg did not nothing to do with it. Infinite cynicism on the part of the Chinese authorities who will refuse to the end to allow the godfather of the Beijing Spring to die with the dignity to which he is entitled. No clemency either for Lee Ming-che, arrested in Taiwan, last March. The activist pays the price for deteriorating relations between China and Taiwan. A very heavy price. His family has not heard from him and fears torture and life imprisonment. Defending democracy on social networks is a sin in Beijing's eyes. So when the twenty most powerful on the planet will meet, tomorrow, in Hamburg, to talk about finance, to talk about the economy and to talk about interconnection, it will be up to Angela Merkel, Emmanuel Macron, Justin Trudeau and all the others to recall that our eyes are also fixed on the fate which will be reserved for Lee, Liu and all the others.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Madam President!Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Peace Prize Laureate, has been sentenced to 11 years in prison for freely speaking his views for no other reason.His wife, Liu Xia, who has not been sentenced to anything, has been held under house arrest for years.Liu Xiaobo and Liu Xia want to be allowed to leave the country now that he has end-stage liver cancer so that they can - for the last few months perhaps - take care of their own health.We all appeal to the Chinese leadership to allow this to happen.Implacability and mercilessness must have a limit!

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this debate concerning Chinese provocations of citizens of both their own state and Taiwan is well timed. As it is the 20th anniversary of the takeover/handover of Hong Kong to the Chinese, I would like to focus my speech on Chinese actions there. One country, two systems was supposed to guarantee the Hong Kong way of life for 50 years, but already Chinese authorities are exerting undue influence on the political, legal and social life of Hong Kong. China must respect the terms of the Sino-British Joint Declaration as a legally binding document lodged with the United Nations. It must respect human rights and release its political prisoners. Similarly, the British Government must do more to uphold our end of the bargain and guarantee the freedoms Hong Kong enjoys under the existing terms of the agreement.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Madam President, it is a fact that human rights are being violated in China. A typical case is the imprisonment, with vague and general charges, of two human rights and democracy activists, the Chinese Liú Xiǎobō, who has also been awarded the Nobel Prize, and the Taiwanese Li Ming-Che. In fact, the former suffers from advanced liver cancer and is not allowed to leave prison either to go home or to a hospital in another country for treatment. Last month, the Greek government did not sign a letter from the European Union to the UN Human Rights Council condemning China for cracking down on dissidents and activists. This behavior of the Greek government did not surprise me. Recently, on the occasion of an insignificant incident, the Speaker of the Parliament forbade all the deputies of my party, of the Golden Dawn, the third political force of the country, to participate in the national delegations of the Parliament. In this way the Greek government has proved that it possesses a totalitarian mentality, adopts the unacceptable principle of collective responsibility and kills democracy in the country in which it was born. I am sure you also condemn the attitude of the Chinese government in the case of the two activists. Do you find any mitigation for the attitude of the Greek government?

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ‘I have no enemies and no hatred’ wrote Liu Xiaobo in his Nobel lecture in absentia in 2010, while serving his 11-year prison sentence for inciting subversion of state power. Today the words of the Nobel laureate and the empty chair at the ceremony resonate strongly. Diagnosed as terminally ill, he is now on medical parole but remains under tight control, and his wish to get medical treatment abroad has been rejected. For Beijing, China’s best known political prisoner and civil rights campaigner is simply a criminal, but for Chinese civil society and human rights defenders he has been the greatest source of inspiration in their peaceful struggle for democratic reform in Communist China. He continues to be a source of inspiration for all of us who have embraced human rights, the rule of law and democracy and rejected every form of totalitarianism. This is the only path we can follow as partners of the Chinese Government and the only path that can guarantee the protection of human dignity.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: - The repeated and long-term detention of the outstanding writer and dissident Liu Xiaobo is an incredible scandal and I hope that the voice of this House will reach Beijing and will help to change the tragic situation of this outstanding man.Lee Ming-che's situation is an emanation not only of China's policy, which repeatedly violates human rights, but also its policy towards Taiwan.Lee Min-che was detained on completely fabricated charges and these charges of subversive activity remind me of the worst times of Stalinism in Poland and of martial law.They should be released immediately.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Madam President! China is a great country, a great power and a great economy, which we in Europe are mutually opening up to. But it is important that, as a major trading area in the EU, in connection with this opening to China, we also take care of the human rights situation in the country. Although there have been major economic and social openings, the situation of individual human rights is still at too low a level in China. That is why it is important for the European Parliament to continue to put pressure on us to improve the human rights situation, both for the Chinese living on the mainland, but also to ensure Taiwan's security in relation to China not being able to press its democratic little brother out in a further aggravated situation. That is why it is important that in our approach to China we are both pragmatic in the economic field and that we also always remember that we must promote human rights when China now has an interest in trading with a large market like the EU.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Liu Xiaobo and Lee Ming-che have very different life paths. Liu Xiaobo is the most celebrated Chinese dissident, Nobel Peace Prize winner in 2010. Lee Ming-che was until recently a discreet volunteer teacher at a local Taiwanese NGO. A common feature, the defense of human rights brought their destinies closer. Both were accused of subversion and sentenced to prison terms by the Chinese regime. Lee Ming-che has been in prison since March in an uncertain part and the Nobel Peace Prize, sentenced in 2009 to 11 years in prison, was released for medical reasons months after being diagnosed with terminal liver cancer and is currently prevented by the Chinese authorities to receive medical treatment abroad, as they wish. Dear Colleagues, in the year that celebrates the 28th anniversary of the Tiananmen massacre, the European Union must clearly condemn the intensification of the repression of freedom of expression and religion that has been taking place in China since 2011, and demand the immediate release of all prisoners of conscience in that country and ask the Chinese authorities to allow historic activist Liu Xiaobo to receive wherever he wants the urgent treatment he so badly needs.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, "I have no enemies, I have no hatred" said Liu Xiaobo, during his hunger strike, during the Tiananmen movement, in 1989, and this 21 years before be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. A prize he was never able to recover in Oslo because he was jailed for 11 years for, I quote: "inciting the subversion of the state". "I have no enemies, I have no hatred", could have said Lee Ming-che, this Taiwanese educator and activist, kidnapped by the Chinese People's Republic, because suspected, I still quote: "of activities endangering the security of the State ”. “She has enemies and so much hatred,” you might say of China, when you look at the number of political dissidents who, year after year, continue to be arrested and imprisoned. When will the European Union emerge from its diplomatic timidity and finally have the courage to unanimously denounce these human rights violations by China, which is putting men behind bars, including the only "Vice" is to have freely expressed themselves?

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - It is unbelievable how many times the issue of human rights is overridden by politics and economic necessity. Indeed, the Union could stand up more strongly for the protection of human rights. And you could do this, above all, if you set an example in the issue and protection of human rights within the Union. Only an inclusive, socially sensitive, equitable and at the same time sustainable economy, with an ever-rising standard of living and security, can be attractive to the rest of the world. Let us make this a reality within the Union, and then it will be easier to convince the Chinese that they must follow this path. It is incredible to just think about how or not the Dalai Lama is received by some political leaders because they are afraid and terrified of China. Where is the Union's human position? Where is the protection of human rights? Let's pay attention to this!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
