text: - Madam President, I would like to sign the motion for a resolution on this point and I would also like to support the two named in this motion for a resolution.I would allow myself to look at another circumstance.Indeed, China has signed a number of human rights treaties over the past 70 years since the end of World War II, and is fundamentally shamelessly violating them.I think we need to have a dialogue with China, we need to talk because we can.And the fact is that many people in China can't talk.We are safe and we are sending a number of delegations to China on behalf of the institutions of the European Union, I think we should really take every such opportunity and talk about serious human rights violations in every such delegation.We, when we can, should really have a dialogue and we have a duty.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, since the detention and conviction of Mr Liu Xiaobo in 2009, the European Union has been following his case closely and advocating that he be released. This has been done both through bilateral meetings with the Chinese authorities and of course through public statements. We are extremely saddened at the recent news about Mr Liu’s health and I want to underline that we stand ready to provide all necessary assistance for Mr Liu and his wife, if they wish to receive medical care in the European Union. According to our information, Mr Liu and his wife cannot move or communicate freely and are not being allowed to receive medical care at a place of their choice, whether in China or overseas.  We are continuing to urge China to allow Mr Liu and his family to meet, and receive visits from, anyone they wish and to communicate freely with the outside world. We have also been concerned about the videos which appear to show Mr Liu receiving medical treatment and his family expressing gratitude for the medical care that he has received. We do not believe that any individual should be videotaped or otherwise recorded without their express consent. A word about Mr Lee Ming-che. The European Union has been following Mr Lee’s case since he disappeared last March. Mr Lee was detained by the Chinese authorities for exercising his right of freedom of expression and opinion, which should be guaranteed under China’s Constitution and its international human rights commitments. We also have reason to believe that Mr Lee is being held at an undisclosed location under what is called residential surveillance at a designated location, which is provided for by China’s criminal procedure law.  In its December 2015 review of China’s conduct, the UN Committee Against Torture recommended that such residential surveillance should be repealed ‘as a matter of urgency’, as it could increase the risk of mistreatment. Mr Lee should be held in a recognised state facility. The Chinese authorities should clarify his place of detention immediately and allow him access to his family and a lawyer of his own choosing. Regarding the fact that there was no EU item for a statement at the June session of the UN Human Rights Council, the EU continues to advocate addressing country situations of concern at the Human Rights Council by leaving several country-specific resolutions under individual items and actively intervening in the Council’s general debates and interactive dialogue under the relevant agenda items. The global human rights agenda is, frankly, best served when the European Union speaks with one voice. We will continue our work to bring all 28 together and to align positions for the next Human Rights Council in order to stand strong and united on these important issues.

name: Die Präsidentin
text: .- The debate is closed.The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Eritrea, in particular the cases of Abune Antonios and Dawit Isaak (2017/2755 (RSP)).

name: Bodil Valero
text: Author. - Madam President! I choose to talk about the Swedish citizen Dawit Isaak who is imprisoned without trial in Eritrea. In the shadow of the terrorist attacks in the United States on September 11, 2001, the President of Eritrea took the opportunity to put an end to all criticism of the country's leadership. The independent press was shut down, politicians, government officials and at least 11 journalists were arrested without trial, among them Dawit Isaak. Violations of human rights in Eritrea do not end despite all the pressure from the outside world. The commitment to Dawit's release is strong in Sweden. According to a report in Dagens Nyheter 2010, Dawit lived as prisoner no. 36 in a desolate prison, chained underground. The cells are said to be moist, overcrowded and dangerous to health. The prisoners have poor access to water and starve, but the most important thing in the article can still be said to be that it was confirmed from credible sources that Dawit Isaak was still alive at the time. In the same year, a representative of the Eritrean regime stated that Dawit Isaak could never expect a trial, as he, along with other prisoners, was alleged to pose a threat to the Eritrean nation's existence. Dawit's family lives in total uncertainty, so do the rest of us. That is why this resolution is so important today.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Madam President, the S&D Group is committed to working for the observance of all fundamental human rights. That is why we initiated this resolution. We are seeing an increase in violence directed against journalists and democracy and human-rights activists across the world. Sixteen years have passed – that is how long Dawit Isaak and other journalists and democracy activists have been imprisoned in Eritrea. Dawit has become a symbol for the struggle for human rights and press freedom. But for many people he is more than a symbol. Back home in Sweden, where he has his loved ones, he is dearly missed, as are the other imprisoned journalists. Sixteen years have passed, and this is our message to the Eritrean Government: at least let us hear from him! Our message to the Commission is: hear us! This Parliament has repeatedly stated that no development cooperation can be pursued with the Eritrean Government as long as they do not respect human rights and set Dawit Isaak and others free. Yet major aid to Eritrea under the European Development Fund has been resumed and a EUR 200 million National Indicative Programme has been signed off. Our resolution denounces this renewal of business as usual. This money cannot go to the Eritrean Government. It must be used to promote democracy and human rights, in the hands of civil society, with not a single cent to the regime. We will not forget about Dawit Isaak and others. We will not let them down.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: Author. - Madam President! He is a Swedish and Eritrean journalist who has been imprisoned for more than 15 years without a lawyer or trial. Completely cut off from his family. He is the EU's only prisoner of conscience. His name is Dawit Isaak. Dawit showed fantastic courage as a journalist. At the risk of his own life, he dared to stand up for his fellow human beings and tell their stories and life stories. The pen was his weapon when he fought for freedom of speech and other human rights. Today he is imprisoned. Eritrea's crimes against humanity must not continue undisturbed. It is high time now for the Swedish government and for the European Commission to finally use tangible pressure on Eritrea. We must introduce a travel ban to the EU for leading figures in the Eritrean regime. We must stop the illegal tax collection of EU citizens of Eritrean origin that is taking place in the Member States and demand that human rights be finally respected in Eritrea. To stand up and defend democracy and human rights and freedoms is our most important task in the EU. At home and around the world. Together we can break down the most powerful walls of oppression and resistance. Dawit Isaac's brave fight against dictatorship deserves to be awarded the Sakharov Prize this year, and I intend to nominate him for that. Now it is our responsibility to use our voice, the voice that Dawit Isaak has been deprived of. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Wikström, you said that Dawit Isaak was Europe’s only prisoner of conscience. That is not true, you know, because elsewhere there are other such cases – for instance in Ethiopia, where the British Ethiopian citizen Andy Tsege has been kidnapped and is in prison. No matter how much solidarity I have with you on the fate of Dawit Isaak, it is incorrect to say that he is the only one.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I don’t think we should quarrel about this. Dawit Isaak has been a prisoner of conscience for a very long time – more than 15, almost 16 years – and if there is now another one, then it is even worse. So let us join forces and fight for both of them. If there are any more prisoners of conscience, it is only proof that we have not done enough.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, given the brutal regime of President Afwerki in Eritrea and his role in ruining that country’s prospects, following its independence from Ethiopia in 1991, we often focus on the wider diplomatic picture. But today we are focusing on two individuals, Abune Antonios and Dawit Isaak. Antonios, the Patriarch of the Eritrean Orthodox Church, has been under house arrest for the past decade. Isaak, a naturalised Swede and a journalist, has been in jail for more than 15 years and has not been seen since 2005. Jailed for his reporting of the corruption and injustices of the Afwerki regime, his case is emblematic of the totalitarian dictatorship that we now see in Eritrea, a regime that sees thousands of young men fleeing conscription and the brutalities of daily life. With 416 000 Eritrean refugees worldwide, this makes it the ninth largest country of origin for refugees, a staggering figure for a country with a population of only 6 million people. Therefore I now call on Parliament and the Commission to consider consultation under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement. I actually called for this almost 18 years ago for the first time and I am calling for it again.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author.- Madam President, yes, Dawit Isaak is a symbol.A Swedish-Eritrean journalist, he was arrested in September 2001 along with dozens of others as the country fell into dictatorship.In Eritrea, there has been no free press since that date.Abune Antonios, former Patriarch of the Orthodox Church, is another symbol.He was jailed in 2016 for refusing to excommunicate 3,000 of his parishioners who opposed the regime.In recent months, things have seemed to be getting worse.(The president interrupts the speaker)

name: President. –
text: What is the problem?

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, there is no interpretation into Czech, so I do not know if the system is functioning.

name: President. –
text: It is working now. Ms Vergiat, you get another 20 to 30 seconds.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Madam President, at least 30 seconds because it was barely 30 when I was interrupted. I need to find where I am, by the way. I repeat a sentence, I'm sorry, please be indulgent. In recent months, things have seemed to be getting worse. The UN special rapporteur speaks of systematic and widespread violations that can constitute crimes against humanity. This is the moment that the European Union chooses to make Eritrea a partner of the “Better Migration Management” project and grant it 46 million euros, plus 5 million via the ROCK program intended for the training of police officers and border guards. We are told that the Eritrean government will not directly benefit from these funds. Let me be skeptical, it's just impossible in this country to do anything without going through the government. What's the next step? The deportation of Eritreans to their country of origin? The Union cannot continue to endorse the regimes which are at the very origin of migration.

name: Lars Adaktusson
text: author. – Madam President, Eritrea is one of the most ruthless dictatorships in the world. President Isaias Afwerki has imposed a rule of fear through extreme abuses against his own people. The evil acts of Afwerki amount to crimes against humanity. He has jailed at least 10 000 political prisoners. Today we are focusing on two of these prisoners – two innocent individuals whose lives have been destroyed by Afwerki. Let us never give up the struggle for Dawit Isaak and Abune Antonios. Let us never forget their remarkable courage. Right now three measures are crucial: aid to Eritrea has to be strictly conditional; the illegal diaspora tax has to be halted in all EU Member States; and Afwerki and his patrons should be prosecuted for crimes against humanity. The brave people of Eritrea deserve to live in freedom. We have a responsibility to assist them towards a brighter future.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: for the PPE Group.- Madam President, I would like to say that the situation in Eritrea has been serious for a long time.The political situation of a country that does not comply with any international treaties is a deterrent.There is no system of national elections, an independent judiciary or the rule of law, which is clear to me that it is the largest authoritarian regime in the world.Therefore, I fully agree with the approach of the European Union and I believe that even stronger measures need to be put in place.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: for the S&D group.- Madam President!This watch shows the time stolen from Dawit Isaak.It is close to 16 years of captivity, close to 16 years of uncertainty and concern for his loved ones.The European Parliament agrees here today to put pressure on the Eritrean Government to act.We've said it before, and we'll say it again.We call on Eritrea to immediately reaffirm the well-being of Dawit Isaac.Release him.Put him in touch with legal representatives and especially with his family.Words and promises are not enough.Action is now required.We need to know that he is alive and well.We also demand the end of detention of opposition, journalists and innocent civilians.Here, Madam President, 5764 days, 23 hours, eleven minutes and now also 6 seconds.For so long, Dawit Isaac's time has been stolen from him.That's enough now.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I want to support this resolution that we are adopting today. It concerns two prisoners of conscience, Mr Antonio and Mr Isaak, but it must be said that, overall, the regime in Eritrea is one of the worst in the world today. It is a regime that violates fundamental human rights at all, more or less towards citizens in the style that citizens are perceived as slaves who must join the army without stating the length of time they have to serve in the army. There are catastrophic conditions for the liquidation of the political opposition, journalists, the clergy, and it is good that the resolution we are adopting today addresses the idea that we should really cancel the country's economic support, because the money we send there is stolen by the corrupt government anyway. , a corrupt president and will not get among the population. So I welcome the resolution and I am glad that, in addition to the fate of the two prisoners, which has been described in detail here, we are assessing the situation in this unfortunate country as a whole.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Eritrean-Swedish journalist Dawit Isaak is one of thousands of prisoners in Eritrea about whom we know nothing. The revered patriarch Antonios dared to protest against arbitrary arrests and was removed and made to disappear. Isaias Afwerki's regime has for years subjected the Eritrean people to a regime of terror, with torture, arbitrary arrests, disappearances, undefined military recruitment, forced labor, etc. It is no wonder that so many Eritreans risk their lives in dangerous crossings in search of refuge. . Instead of working strategically with other partners to alleviate the suffering of the Eritreans and to welcome those fleeing, the European Union has negotiated with the Government of Isaias Afwerki 200 million euros from the EDF for unconditional investments to stop the refugee outbreak. This policy is not just a waste of public money, it is a betrayal of the values ​​that should guide our foreign and development policy in order to make a difference for Eritreans and that implies promoting democratic transformation in Eritrea.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the situation in Eritrea is now out of control due to the political persecution carried out by the regime, but also due to the unlimited compulsory military service. Thus, more than 400,000 people, or 9% of the country's population, have fled Eritrea, increasing refugee flows to Europe. Sexual violence, not only against women but also in training camps, is on the agenda. At the same time, the regime completes its control against the population, imposing a 2% income tax on expatriates. The victims of the regime are Abune Antonios, the patriarch of the Eritrean Orthodox Church, the largest religious community, who has been detained for ten years since 2007 for refusing to expel 3,000 parishioners who opposed the government. . Activist Dawit Isaak is also in custody. Immediate release of all political prisoners!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is í an Eiritré an tír is measa ar domhan ó thaobh cearta daonna de agus tá sé ag éirí níos measa de réir na bliana. Tá gach saghas éagóir ar siúl ann, go háirithe le mná agus leanaí agus ní nach ionadh go bhfuil daoine ag teitheadh ón dtír. Tá 400,000 duine tar éis an tír a fhágáil. Freisin, maidir le Dawit Isaak, gabhadh é in 2001. An bhfuil sé beo? Níl a fhios againn, ach tá sé de dhualgas ar an rialtas insint dá chlann agus do chuile dhuine mar gheall air. Freisin mar gheall ar an Patrarc Antonios. Tá sé i bpríosún ó 2007 in áit anaithnid agus deirtear nach bhfuil cóir leighis ar fáil aige.  Dá bhrí sin is dóigh liom gur cheart dúinne gan aon airgead a thabhairt don Eiritré. Táimid ag tabhairt €200 milliún dóibh agus is dóigh liom gur cheart cosc a chur air sin go dtí go bhfaighimid freagra ar na ceisteanna seo.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, regretfully we do not see any improvement with regard to human rights violations in Eritrea. A huge number of Eritrean people, including children, are still being arrested for various unjustifiable reasons and held in extremely harsh conditions. Dawit Isaak’s incarceration has become an international symbol for the struggle for freedom of the press in Eritrea. He should be immediately and unconditionally released, together with all prisoners of conscience. In addition, Abune Antonios should be allowed to return to his position as Patriarch. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right, and any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion must be condemned. Commissioner, as you know, as chair of Working Group A of the Committee on Development, I oppose the granting of money under the National Indicative Programme for Eritrea until these issues are resolved: until the prisoners are released, the Patriarch is reinstated and this autocratic dictatorship, which is not acceptable, has come to an end.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to point out that I agree with all my predecessors and I will not describe the situation in Eritrea as has already been said. Eritrea is one of the youngest states, but one that is facing the worst human rights violations, massive, various human rights violations. I think that the proposal that has been made and is contained in the resolution, so that the aid is conditionally stopped, I think it is very, very strong. We should want the money provided by the European Union to have specifically measurable effects in certain steps. It is not possible to send money in situations where we do not receive answers to our questions. And the resolution, which concerns only two people, are, of course, those who are so enlightened, but there are thousands of other nameless and thousands of people who suffer under a regime whose only main force is to recruit a tenth of their citizens into their army. That, I think, should be a fundamental memento for us.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the Eritrean population has been going through an ordeal for too long. Behind closed doors in this country which recently acquired its independence, a human and political drama is playing out. Dawit Isaak has become an international symbol, but many other citizens, especially women, suffer the denial of their basic rights and suffer violence. There is no other term than "slavery" to describe what the 400,000 people are currently enlisted in what the local authorities modestly call "national service". The European Union is supporting Eritrea significantly - with funding around 200 million euros - and has the right, it seems to me, but also the duty, to act, by making its aid conditional on compliance. minimum human rights. I also call on Member States to welcome Eritrean asylum seekers, who would be sentenced to hell if returned to their country.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the issue of human-rights violations in Eritrea is a serious issue, but it is no more serious than the situation in a whole host of countries in Africa that we continue to support. I think it is very important that, in this motion, we once again send a clear message to the Eritrean Government in relation to those human-rights violations. Unlike other colleagues, I still believe that engagement with Eritrea is important. It is a country caught in a time warp. It is a country that needs to understand the obligations under international law that we, as EU citizens, demand. That is why I went to Eritrea last year. I suspect that I am the only member of this assembly speaking here today who has actually been to Eritrea in the past 12 months. I would ask other colleagues to do the same because it is only through engagement that we can actually change policy in Eritrea. It is only through reaching out that we can change policy in Eritrea. I want to put on the record that the EU funds that have come through the development budget have made a big difference to the lives of ordinary people – ordinary Eritreans – in terms of solar power, electricity connectivity, building capacity within the judicial system and in other systems of government. It is important that we remain committed to funding Eritrea and that we have a more balanced approach in this whole debate.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, there is no doubt that I share the honourable Members’ frustration about the situation in Eritrea, and maybe if I still had my former position as an MEP I would say that enough is enough, but now I am on the other side in this plenary. The European Union is concerned over continued human-rights violations in Eritrea and, in particular, about the cases of His Holiness Abune Antonios and Dawit Isaak. Respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms is, for all of us, a core value of the European Union and a key priority in EU internal and external policy. It therefore features regularly in our political dialogue with the Eritrean authorities. The case of Dawit Isaak has been of major concern since his arbitrary arrest in September 2001. His continued detention since then, without charges, trial or legal counsel, represents a serious violation of international obligations by Eritrea. The same applies in respect of the other 10 independent journalists, and honourable Members have already focused on this. We are also worried about the situation of His Holiness Abune Antonios, Patriarch of the Eritrean Orthodox Church, who marks his tenth year of incommunicado house arrest in an unknown location, although he has never been charged with any offence. We regularly address these issues at the highest level of the Government of Eritrea and draw attention to them in international forums, including the United Nations Human Rights Council. Since 2001, the EU has regularly issued statements calling for the immediate and unconditional release of political prisoners in Eritrea. The Union also regularly asks the Eritrean authorities to take all necessary steps to comply with their international commitments, including on freedom of religion or belief and freedom of expression, association and assembly. In line with the resolution of the UN Human Rights Council on the human-rights situation in Eritrea which was adopted in June this year, the EU continues to engage with Eritrea with a view to improving the human-rights situation on the ground. The EU will support the full implementation of the recommendations made to Eritrea under the UN-led Universal Periodic Review. The EU will continue to press for an improvement in the human-rights situation in Eritrea and urge the Government of Eritrea to release the political prisoners, including Dawit Isaak. Moreover, the EU shall request that all information on the whereabouts of these prisoners is made public and that they have access to their families and lawyers, not least on humanitarian grounds. At the same time, the EU will continue to promote freedom of religion or belief – a right that should be exercised everywhere by all – on the basis of the principles of universality, equality and non-discrimination.

name: Die Präsidentin
text: .- The debate is closed.The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I would like to point out to the Commissioner that many of us have questioned him on the issue of funds allocated by the European Union and that we have not received any response on the matter.I think that that's too bad.

name: Die Präsidentin.
text: - Commissioner!Do you still have an answer to the question of financing that Madame Vergiat has now raised again?

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am not ready to answer these questions today. I can, of course, respect this request but it is difficult to give an immediate answer. I would like to give a written answer.

name: President. –
text: Thank you. We will expect your answer.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Burundi (2017/2756 (RSP)).

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author.- After a debate on Eritrea, another very, very dark chapter.In April 2015, the President of Burundi, President Nkurunziza, sought a third term.And now, in July 2017, 400,000 people have fled, 200,000 people have fled domestically, 3 million people in need, two and a half million people who are unsure whether they will have anything to eat tomorrow and 700,000 people in urgent need of food aid.And that because of a man who wanted to reign four to five years longer.Nkurunziza is also engaged in ethnic cleansing in his army, with the whole distinction between Hutus and Tutsis returning and the repercussions on the region we can expect.Destabilizing Burundi is destabilizing the countries around it and I am concerned that we will face a civil war that will affect all those countries again.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, the re-election of President Nkurunziza in 2015 was highly controversial, given the questions surrounding the legitimacy of his eligibility for a third term, and in fact Article 96 consultation was invoked. The boycott of that election by the opposition and his subsequent re-election has provoked increasing tension. Recent speculation that Nkurunziza is  seeking to amend the law so as to allow him to run again in 2020 for a fourth term is concerning. Meanwhile, the resulting human rights situation is also very worrying. Nkurunziza’s party’s youth wing and quasi-militia, the Imbonerakure, is held responsible for the intimidation, rape, attack and forced disappearances of a number of opposition figures and supporters. Given the fragility and conflict in Burundi’s neighbouring states, finding a way through the impasse is vital. There are reports of an increasingly ethnic dimension – between Hutus and Tutsis – to the violence, and this has the potential to significantly worsen and protract the problem. Therefore we must all now seek action before the situation reaches that terrible point.

name: Maria Arena
text: author. - Madam President, Burundi is a ravaged country today. Since April 2015, after Nkurunziza's decision not to respect the Constitution, the country has entered a vicious cycle of repression. In two years, 1,200 killed, between 400 and 900 victims of disappearances, thousands of arbitrary arrests, more than 40,000 Burundians displaced, and this in a disastrous socio-economic situation that weighs on the entire Burundian population. The violence is committed by the Burundian security services and by militias who also act on their orders. A political landscape with a single party, a media landscape reduced to nothing, a justice totally at the service of the regime and, as if this table were not enough, Nkurunziza is trying to change the Constitution in order to be able to establish a dictatorship beyond 2020. In background, we also live ethnic discrimination which becomes a daily reality. Nkurunziza instrumentalizes the political crisis by transforming it into an ethnic crisis. We are asking for several things in the resolution: the first, the fight against impunity; the second, to subordinate any relationship with the country to an improvement in the human rights situation; the third, the support of the United Nations. We also call for support for the efforts of the East African Community and for transparency in the funding of Burundian soldiers compared to the militia in Somalia.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: author. – Madam President, this is not the first time that we have discussed the situation in Burundi. Since April 2015, there has been an alarming deterioration of human rights and a severe humanitarian crisis in the country. Those opposing the President’s legitimate re-election are facing a massive clampdown and violations of their rights. Respect for the opposition, free and fair elections and freedom of speech are fundamental to any democracy. We must condemn these acts of violence and other human rights abuses in Burundi. We must be clear that we cannot allow the situation to continue. We must ensure that the EU targeted sanctions are fully implemented, effective and further extended until we see real reform in the country. The EU Member States and the Union should speak was one voice on Burundi and do all that they can to finally bring about peaceful coexistence among the nations of the Great Lakes region, working together with the UN and the African Union. Burundi has come a long way since its independence. We must take action now to help bring peace to this region.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the fifth resolution on Burundi that we have been writing since the beginning of this legislature. It pains me enormously to see how, two years after we condemned the violence in the country and Nkurunziza's willingness to participate in the elections again, in violation of the country's constitution and the Arusha agreements, the situation has only worsened not to say rush. Government security forces, authorities and militias continue to violate the most basic human rights. The Imbonerakure, the fearsome youth militia, goes further, publicly inciting to rape the wives of political opponents, recruiting and plagiarizing young students, as the country plunges into a devastating economic and social crisis. We therefore ask the High Representative to extend the European sanctions, to use all the tools at his disposal to try to defuse a dangerous escalation, and in particular the further ethnicization of the crisis, a prelude to a point of no return for the population. As Eliezer Wiesel, winner of a Nobel Peace Prize, said, "Never again" must be more than a slogan, it must be a prayer, a promise, an oath, an invitation to all of us in this House and to the entire international community. not to tolerate that the atrocities of the past can be repeated again.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Madam President, since the spring of 2015, Burundi has been sinking into crisis. President Nkurunziza wants to stay in power for a third and now even a fourth term, calling into question the Arusha accords and raising the specter of civil war. Thousands of opponents are silenced, including inside the president's one-party party. The repression is becoming more and more violent, militarized in the hands of militias, in particular Imbonerakure, the youth league of the president's party. The ethnic question is instrumentalized and the UN itself speaks of the risk of genocide. The worst is feared in this neighboring country of Rwanda, as the whole region risks being destabilized. The international community was slow to react. However, targeted sanctions have been taken, notably by the European Union. Within the GUE / NGL group, we are skeptical about sending military forces and consider that political solutions should be given priority. But here they are far from obvious. So, yes, we must help Burundian refugees, including by facilitating their arrival on European Union soil.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Author. - Mister President! Since President Pierre Nkurunziza announced in April 2015 that he was seeking another term in office, which the Constitution of Burundi excludes, Burundi has been sinking into a spiral of violence and disregard for civil and human rights. The opposition is brutally suppressed, thousands of people have already been murdered, tens of thousands have been forced to go into hiding and more than 400,000 Burundi residents have fled to neighboring countries, threatening stability in the region. The rulers of Burundi refuse to enter into a dialogue both with the international community and with social forces in their own country. On the contrary: The independent international commission of inquiry of the United Nations in Burundi found that there was ample evidence of extensive violations of human rights and abuse of power in Burundi, perpetrated in particular by the youth organization of the President's party, Imbonerakure, but also by the Burundi military, what This is all the more serious since the EU also pays Burundian soldiers as part of the African Union mission in Somalia. All measures - including further sanctions - must be taken to increase the pressure on President Nkurunziza and the rulers in Burundi to finally open up to a dialogue.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I must say that I am deeply concerned to learn of the growing conflict in Burundi following the unconstitutional re—election of President Pierre Nkurunziza in 2015 and his intention to be re-elected again in 2020 and probably ad infinitum. The deplorable human-rights situation and the authorities’ continued violation of fundamental rights are totally unacceptable. I therefore strongly support calls for the Burundian authorities to address these violations and to conduct an independent inquiry so that the perpetrators can be held accountable. Furthermore, Burundi must revoke its move to withdraw from the International Criminal Court and must extend full support to the office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights so as to ensure fundamental rights for all its citizens, because the abuses of fundamental rights – the murder, rape, abduction, etcetera – in Burundi are absolutely chronic and must be stopped.

name: David Martin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, in 2015, in Burundi, I witnessed at first hand Government troops blowing up a radio antenna in order to stop independent radio stations broadcasting, I met families who had been burnt out of their houses because they were of the wrong ethnicity, and I saw political rallies brutally broken up by government-backed militia. When I raised all of these issues at the recent meeting of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) in Malta, the Burundian representative admitted – what else could he do, I had seen it with my own eyes – that all of these events had happened, but said that things were much better now in the country. Well, I am afraid things are not much better in the country, and what we hear from the international community and the international organisations based in Burundi is that, in fact, things are getting worse. This is a time for us to intensify our sanctions on Burundi, to make sure we keep the pressure up on the current Burundian Government, and to ask the East African Community to act to defend their neighbour’s citizens.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - As many of us have said here, the situation in Burundi is shocking. And while there are quite a few presidents in the region who are aiming for a third term in office, the president of Burundi even goes one step further. He would like to go to a fourth term. That will now become the standard. To do that, to maintain that absolute power, he and his supporters are willing to go very far. We have already heard many things here: aid convoys are no longer allowed in, international observers are banned. What really worries me is that ethnic cleansing is now also underway. More than 100 Tutsi soldiers have been killed! I went to Rwanda together with Louis Michel and Guy Verhofstadt. We have seen crates with skulls, crates with hands and chests with feet. Ethnic cleansing is horrible and if you now feel that it is going to spread to Burundi, it worries me. We must do everything we can to give the country the rest it deserves again. Africa needs our support, so we must intervene when human rights are violated and violated. So let's argue for an international investigation. Let's make sure the Burundians get the protection they deserve.

name: Tim Aker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this report highlights worrying developments in Burundi, one of Africa’s poorest countries. Since 2015, 1 200 people have been killed and between 400 and 900 have disappeared. The use of torture has been widespread. More than 10 000 people have been detained without trial and nearly half a million have fled to neighbouring countries. Burundi has plunged into crisis. With reports of ethnic cleansing in the military, the world and all global institutions must be ready to intervene and prevent another genocide. There cannot be a repeat of Rwanda. Too often the West has been ready to intervene when the cause has not warranted it – the disaster in Libya being one example – but when there is a call on our resources, too many also look the other way. A strong message from all quarters must go out across the world that the rights to life, liberty and political expression are unbreakable. And all those who believe in that message must have the force, in every sense of the word, to back it up.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen!Burundi, while being one of the poorest countries in the world, is also experiencing a political crisis and serious human rights violations.In my view, therefore, the decision to suspend direct aid to the Burundian Government was right, and this state must continue until Burundi complies with Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement.At the same time, however, the European Union cannot turn its back on the Burundian people.Therefore, efforts to benefit the local community and civil society should continue, as well as intensify assistance to Burundian refugees and internally displaced persons.It is also particularly important to ensure that refugee camps are safe places and to avoid returns that are against the will of the refugees.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Madam President, while Burundi is going through one of its worst security crises, the country's primary and secondary authorities persist in wanting to deny the obvious, as was the case in Malta, in the Joint Assembly ACP-EU. Yet politically, socially and culturally, Burundi strayed from the right path in 2015, when Pierre Nkurunziza decided to run for an unconstitutional third term in office, assassinations and waves of forced exile ensued. We demand concrete commitments from Burundi, in this case on democracy and human rights. On these points, we are ready to sanction Burundian officials even more severely. Naturally, the European Union must remain open to a dialogue with the Burundian government if it shows respect for the principles on which we have insisted for the good of the population. Fostering the various international observation missions mentioned in the resolution then becomes an imperative, because only they can certify possible progress. In the face of totalitarianism, we must remain intransigent.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I support everything that has been said by my colleagues about the tragic situation in Burundi at the moment. It is also true that we have discussed the situation in Burundi several times during this parliamentary term and have written several resolutions, and these unfortunately have no general impact. I would like to hear the Commissioner say if he has any idea how to open up the European Union's diplomacy to Burundi so that the President, who arbitrarily and repeatedly extends his mandate, perceives at least a little bit of the voice of the democratic international community and at least a little respect for human rights and so that there is no future war in Burundi. The situation there is really tragic, there is a risk of serious ethnic conflict. It is good that we are debating this here, but on the other hand I am expressing some skepticism. If the president is not willing to listen at least a little and engage in a little dialogue with the democratic international community, then I fear that the worst may happen. I support the resolution, but I ask the Commission to say what else can be done now.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me start by expressing my concern about the political and security situation in Burundi, which is characterised by ongoing violence, killings, sexual violence and human rights abuses. I am confident that Burundi will resume cooperation with the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in order to comply with its international human rights obligations. Economic relations can be upgraded only if a sustained political solution is reached. The EU should continue its full financial support for the people of Burundi, including humanitarian support provided through direct channels, not through the Government. The EU and Burundi should therefore keep up a dialogue in order to encourage progress in fulfilling the conditions set by the European Union. Finally, I would like to welcome the decision of the African Union’s Peace and Security Council authorising the deployment of an African prevention and protection mission in Burundi to pave the way for a political solution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, we are again in the same project as spectators for Burundi. In the last two years we have dealt at least five times with the illegal actions of the President of Burundi, Nkurunziza, who has literally been in power. He is pursuing his political opponents - 1,200 people have reportedly been killed and more than 10,000 tortured, and the arrests of journalists, lawyers and activists are on the agenda. More than 400,000 people have fled Burundi, 3 million of our fellow human beings need humanitarian aid and all this because Nkurunziza violates the Cotonou Agreement, violates the Constitution and now wants to change the Constitution and secure a fourth term as President of Burundi, something which is certainly not accepted by the citizens of Burundi. Measures and sanctions must therefore be taken against Nkurunziza and his company.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the Republic of Burundi, the radicalization of the regime that followed the announcement of President Pierre Nkurunziza's candidacy for a third term, in violation of the country's Constitution, polarized the political conflict and the harsh reprisals of the government and its militias have condemned opponents to re-election, to exile or to be victims of torture and extrajudicial executions, arbitrary arrests and enforced disappearances. This political crisis and the deteriorating economy have caused a dramatic humanitarian crisis in the country where, at the moment, according to UN estimates, three million people are in need of help and 2.6 million are exposed to extreme food insecurity. In view of this situation, the European Union must urge the authorities of Burundi to comply with the international obligations they have assumed in the field of human rights and to bring those responsible for the atrocities committed to trial. The Union also has a duty to support all negotiation efforts between the government and the opposition that will allow an end to the escalation of ethnic tensions and to find a peaceful and sustainable solution for that country.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I  share your frustration. To the frustration of many, the situation in Burundi is essentially unchanged, with no improvement in any of the key areas that would allow a return to normality, in particular as regards human rights, civil society, the media, disarmament, and justice. In May, the Council therefore agreed that there was currently no basis for changing the Article 96 decision. At the same time, we are continuing to receive reports of serious abuses and violence by security services and militias. More than 400 000 people have sought refuge in neighbouring countries. The Government remains in denial about the state of the country and is not letting United Nations human rights investigators have access, despite the fact that Burundi is itself a member of the UN Human Rights Council.  It is possible that the situation in Burundi might become even more polarised unless the authorities open up to a genuinely inclusive dialogue, observing the principles of the Arusha Agreement, and take practical steps to reduce tension. The European Union will continue to reach out to encourage heads of state in the region to bring their influence to bear, as a matter of urgency, with a view to speeding up the mediation process. This should help to create the necessary conditions, in particular in the areas of human rights and political space, for elections to be held in 2020, thus fully complying with the Arusha Peace Agreement and the Constitution. The European Union has repeatedly stated that it is ready to respond to progress reached in President Mkapa’s mediation, acting under the Article 96 decision. The absence of the rule of law and the resulting adverse impact on human rights and freedoms – as well as on the already very poor economic and social indicators – have led to an alarming deterioration in the living conditions of the population.  The European Union will continue to alleviate the population’s plight   through direct support, with a focus on building resilience by supporting basic livelihoods (agriculture and nutrition actions) and improving access to basic social services such as health care. An additional package of EUR 95 million has recently been approved. In addition, the EU supports – through the African Peace Facility – the African Union human rights observers and military experts in Burundi and we will be seeking to enhance their role on the ground.  Last but not least, we also support the needs of the thousands of Burundian refugees in the region. Uganda, for example, is hosting around 35 000 Burundian refugees, among others. I was in Uganda to represent the European Union at the Solidarity Summit convened by UN Secretary—General António Guterres and there I announced EU emergency assistance of EUR 85 million for the whole refugee and IDP package.  (Applause)

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, yesterday afternoon we had a lively debate, under Rule 153, on the subject of a single seat for this Parliament. Unfortunately, under that rule, it was not possible to have a resolution, but it was the clear will of this House that we bring forward a report to propose a treaty change. So, as Mr Weber and Mr Pittella are in their seats, could they please take note of the view of this House and, when the matter comes to the Conference of Presidents, could they please authorise that report? (Applause)

name: Der Präsident.
text: - Thank you very much, Mr Fox, even if that was just off the point of order.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I want to ask my colleagues for patience, a minute so that together we condemn the bloody events of yesterday in the Venezuelan Assembly.Our colleagues, deputies, were violated in their legitimate task of popular representation by uncontrolled mobs close to the Chavista regime.I ask all our colleagues not to close their eyes, ears and mouths to such an execrable action: let us remember that, in three months, 91 people have died on the streets of Venezuela.And I want to add this: the terrible images that we have seen right now of the bloodied deputies in the Assembly ... perhaps it is time to consider a clear action and ask, at once, for sanctions against the Venezuelan regime so that it is understood,Please understand once and for all, that here in Europe we stand for freedom, democracy and our colleagues in the Venezuelan Assembly.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr López-Istúriz White!Here, too, I would have been grateful if I had been helped to find the relevant provision of the rules of procedure for this important matter.

name: Kati Piri
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, ahead of the vote on Turkey, I would like to draw your attention to what happened last night when eight human-rights defenders, including the director of Amnesty International in Turkey, were detained in Istanbul. One German and one Swedish national are also currently being detained. It is not clear where they are being held and they do not have access to their lawyers. This is the moment for this Parliament to call on the Turkish authorities for the immediate release of these human-rights defenders in Turkey. (Applause)

name: Renate Sommer (PPE).
text: - Mister President!The EPP has tabled an oral amendment to paragraph 16. At the end of the paragraph it says: “is concerned about the recent seizure of the churches in the region of Diyarbakir”, and we would like to add: “urges the government to return them to theirrightful owners ".This oral amendment has been discussed with the rapporteur, Kati Piri, and she is in agreement with this oral amendment.So I ask for your approval.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, it is a point of order. It is about the way that you are conducting the vote. What I am getting through my headphones is ‘for, against, abstain, for, against, abstain, for, against, abstain’. It is impossible to vote if we are going at that speed.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - Mr Batten!To take note again: The vote was open.I am not giving a word of order.Then I closed the vote and then I gave you the floor.That is the common practice.Unfortunately, I now have no opportunity to put your request to the vote.But I think the House's reaction has shown that most of them will come along.(Applause) - Before the vote on Amendment 10:

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, unless I am mistaken, I believe that we did not vote on Amendment 74. It was a roll call vote.Perhaps it is obsolete?

name: Der Präsident.
text: - Mr Tarabella!The services tell me that if Amendment 64 is adopted, Amendment 74 will be closed.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the other day, during the visit of the Maltese Prime Minister, President Juncker said that this Parliament was ridiculous, or pointless or a farce, or something to that effect. The obscene speed at which these votes are being conducted most certainly gives weight to President Juncker’s view. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Der Präsident.
text: - Mr Coburn!Thank you for this important contribution.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - That closes voting time.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report and I would like to note that we have already adopted one resolution on Turkey in relation to the failed military coup in July 2016. In that resolution, despite highlighting that Turkey remains a strategic partner of the EU, we expressed serious concern about the multiple incompatibilities with progress towards accession, and called for a temporary freeze of Turkey’s EU accession talks. However, it seems that, since then, the situation has only got worse and that the one-man rule is being strengthened. We have seen continuous arrests, a referendum to authorise undemocratic constitutional changes, and far—reaching censorship of the media. I believe that the situation in Turkey can no longer be ignored. If the constitutional reforms package is implemented as it stands now, the EU must stop its accession talks with Turkey immediately, as well as the pre-accession assistance funding.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in retrospect, the European Union’s approach to Turkey has not worked out terribly well. We could, at the outset, have said ‘Membership is not on the agenda: let’s find a different way of working together’, or we could have embraced them, but what we did instead was to hold out a promise of membership which we had absolutely no intention of fulfilling. Understandably, a sense of rejection contributed to some political breakdown in that country. Of course, I am not saying it was all the fault of the European Union. That would be absurd. It is mainly about internal dynamics within Turkey. But I wonder whether we might not be wiser now to try to find a more sustainable and permanent deal, whereby we recognise Turkey as a strategic partner and ally, and recognise the value of a free market with Turkey, but drop the idea of political integration. And if we could set up such a status successfully for a state as important and as large as Turkey, perhaps it could become the model for relations with other nearby neighbouring countries.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate Rapporteur Piri once again on the overall tone of the report, which is deservedly critical of the current leadership of the Republic of Turkey. This is undoubtedly a step in the right direction of the European Union's policy towards the country's processes. I voted in favor of rejecting the report, however, as there are some extremely problematic points. Nowhere is the intensifying process of transforming the Kemalist secular republic into a religious Islamist dictatorship affected. This is not compatible with the values ​​we claim to defend here. Despite criticism of human rights abuses, the report lacks the specific issue, namely Erdogan and the country's Islamization. Moreover, this year we have witnessed an unprecedented and brazen interference by the Republic of Turkey in the internal affairs of countries both in Western Europe and in my homeland - Bulgaria. This should not be allowed, and part of the accession negotiations should not just be frozen, but suspended. A Kemalian Turkey that relies on secular values ​​is a good partner of the Union, it can be an ally. The same cannot be said of an Islamizing dictatorship.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I agree with the two amendments tabled by Members of the ENF Group.Turkey should recognize the Armenian genocide.I also think that, in the interests of the good coexistence of Christians and Muslims, the originally Christian Hagia Sophia in Istanbul should remain a museum and not be reused as a mosque.Nevertheless, I could not support these proposals.The situation in Turkey fills me with concern.I feel that the most important thing today is dialogue, and that is why we need to start first with the topics that we see as key to the relationship between Turkey and the European Union.This resolution is primarily intended to remind the Turkish Government of its obligations and existing contracts.Only then, after re-establishing goodwill and improving relationships, can we try to talk about more sensitive topics again.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this revised European external investment plan proposed by the Commission. Despite being convinced that official development assistance should remain the main source of support to developing countries, I am happy to see that private investment will be used in Africa and the in the EU Eastern and Southern Neighbourhoods as part of a broader strategy to keep migration at bay. It is essential to address the root causes of migration by creating jobs, supporting the development of small and medium-sized businesses and facilitating inclusive growth. The main advantage of the plan is the newly designed instrument, the European Fund for Sustainable Development Fund, and its Guarantee which, with the contributions of the European Investment Bank, will be employed to attract public and private investment and manage risks. I believe this approach will help to produce a sufficient investment-generation process through the instrument we supported, and by providing viable technical assistance to all countries in need.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor and I wanted to intervene, especially in relation to the creation of this new European Fund for Sustainable Development, because without a doubt it is going to tackle the problem of immigration, injustice and poverty. It is going to be earmarked —44 million euros— for investments in Africa and its neighboring countries. At last - I insist - we are going to tackle the underlying problem in Africa and the situation of many injustices. There are some achievements that I would like to highlight because they seem especially essential to me in this Fund: reference to development effectiveness, resilience, decent job creation and poverty eradication goals; the inclusion of the Paris Agreement and the Agenda for Sustainable Development, as the objective of this Fund; or the inclusion of a clause to safeguard human and labor rights. Finally, the inclusion in the text of the fight against tax havens and tax evasion I believe is an important achievement in the objectives of this Fund.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased that today we have adopted legislation transposing the Marrakesh International Agreement on the Access to Copyrighted Copyright Works for the Visually Impaired. This exception will fundamentally affect the quality of life of visually impaired citizens and enable them to participate better in cultural, economic and social life, of course if the Member States also cooperate. At present, a total of 20% of all works are available with the help of alternative methods, especially in Braille, large format or audiobooks. Making the additional 80% available can therefore have a major impact on the study opportunities and overall education of these people, and at the same time it will not affect commercial sales, as these people are simply not involved yet, do not use copyrighted works of art. So I believe that breaking down these barriers will help to improve their quality of life.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am happy that today we are one step closer to ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty. EU action on facilitating access to published works for people who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print disabled has been long overdue. However, despite many of the good points contained in Parliament’s report, I strongly condemn the introduction of compensation schemes for publishers. Not only could this provision violate Article 21 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities but there has been no proof of economic loss to be compensated for, and governments have never demonstrated that any damage is done to publishers by accessibly formatted works. This provision is in direct contradiction with the ‘right to read’ objectives of the Marrakesh Treaty and should be addressed, during the transposition phase, in EU Member State legislation. Nonetheless, I hope EU Member States can give the treaty their approval so that it can finally be ratified this coming autumn.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report takes some steps towards a new sustainable development for Europe, and that is why I voted in favor. However, I must point out that it could have been more ambitious and asked for more binding targets to be adopted, starting with energy saving and individual self-production, to the massive reclamation that must accompany the reconversion of industrial sites. Much attention is rightly given to the reduction of greenhouse gases in the context of climate change, but, for example, the same level of alarm is not attributed to many other pollutants that plague the air, water and soil. Efforts are emerging aimed at the implementation of the circular economy, recovery, reuse and recycling, but we have had to present amendments - not passed - to exclude the incineration of waste from this plant. Attempts are made to increase the role of renewable energies in the energy mix, but the use of the EFSI is accepted, which is widely used to support fossil fuels. Gentlemen, with this proposal we are trying to take a leap forward, but to succeed we would have had to take a good run.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - Mr President, this is an important report - the Goals for Sustainable Development. I want to emphasize in my explanation that I like the evolution that has taken place in the plenary session much more than what was initially approved by the Environment Committee. It is a response to the Commission Communication on European action for sustainability and, what was initially approved in this committee were quite unfair issues with Community agricultural policy. I insist that it has been corrected and that is why I voted favorably. I want to emphasize that this community agricultural policy already in its last reform made great environmental efforts, an aspect as important as greening was incorporated, which is involving important efforts for all European farmers and ranchers. It is not fair to say that European agriculture is not helping the environment: it is doing it; evolving despite having direct competition from products from third countries that do not do the same. Therefore, highlighting the role of European agriculture.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have chosen to abstain on this report because I do not think it says anything and everything. I believe that the term 'sustainability' is already so widely used that it is meaningless. It is neither rational nor useful to discuss so many areas and problems in a single document. The only thing this report leads to is an exchange of views. And while I am inclined to agree with much of what has been said, such as improving air quality and revitalizing rural areas, I cannot accept the proposal to increase funding for official development assistance, the so-called ODA. Experience has shown that blindly pouring money into problem areas of the world through development and sustainability tools simply does not work. I do not think that spending European taxpayers' money on such projects is beneficial. I would support such spending of these instruments only if it is linked to a mandatory increase in security in problem areas and a reduction in immigration pressure on Europe. However, such proposals are lacking. Therefore, despite several useful annexes to the report, I could not support it.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this report of which, incidentally, I was a shadow rapporteur, because I believe that, although sustainable development has long been at the heart of the European project, we still have a long way to go in the building a better future for our children and our planet. The European Parliament has devoted much of its attention to the implementation of the UN 2030 Agenda, which is a common commitment and needs the participation and cooperation of all, including the Member States, and civil society in general. The proposals in this report have in common the objective of strengthening the core of the European Union's overall strategy and provide an opportunity for the European Parliament to anchor its vision, its agenda, on a European action for sustainability in a definitive and decisive way. It is a vast and interesting reflection that responds to the most complex interconnected challenges facing the world today and presents a framework for action for the institutions of the European Union, in particular for the European Parliament. Dear Colleagues, I believe that this House has an undeniable role in creating a better and more sustainable future for Europe and this report may come to be a key part of this plan.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) influence virtually every aspect of the EU’s work. The global 2030 Agenda represents a commitment to achieving sustainable development by 2030 worldwide – a commitment that must be shared by all countries. The aims of this agenda are to work towards human dignity, stability, a healthy planet, fair and resilient societies and prosperous economies. The EU shares these goals and therefore I voted in favour of this motion. By embedding the targets of the SDGs in the framework of EU policies, the EU will ensure that adherence to the aims of the SDGs is a key part of future policy initiatives. In doing so, we are ensuring that the EU will successfully deliver on the 2030 Agenda. Finally, Mr President, may I compliment you on the efficient and calm manner in which you chaired today’s session, contrary to what was said by one or two speakers. They were a tiny minority. The round of applause said it all.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the outermost regions of the European Union, like other less-favored ones, such as the mountains, are an integral part of the European Union. However, given their specific characteristics, such as remoteness, they have more difficult access to the common European market. That is why I believe that these regions must have a special status and targeted and facilitated support through the European Union budget. Cohesion policy is an important tool that creates conditions for economic development and prosperity for these regions, so it must remain after 2020. The remote, as well as the mountainous regions, have the potential to produce quality products. Therefore, they should have simpler rules for the preparation and protection of the relevant quality schemes. I call on the European Commission to provide more targeted tools and information campaigns on protected geographical indications schemes, because these schemes provide valuable opportunities for creating, maintaining and developing livelihoods in remote and mountainous regions.
